dataIdInfo.idAbs: Provides a set of useful depth summary statistics, including mean depth, variance, standard deviation, interquartile range, and kurtosis. These metrics can be helpful predictors in understanding benthic zones, particularly when used for habitat classification.

tool.name: depthstatistics

param.name: Neighborhood_Size
param.dialogReference: The size of the moving window of cells used to calculate each statistic, measured in cell units. For more information, see How Focal Statistics Work
param.pythonReference: The size of the moving window of cells used to calculate each statistic, measured in cell units. For more information, see How Focal Statistics Work

param.name: Window_Type
param.dialogReference: The form of the window: eithe a regular square covering n by n cells, or a circle with a radius n. For more information, see How Focal Statistics Work
param.pythonReference: The form of the window: eithe a regular square covering n by n cells, or a circle with a radius n. For more information, see How Focal Statistics Work

param.name: Output_Workspace
param.dialogReference: Output workspace for results produced by this tool.
param.pythonReference: Output workspace for results produced by this tool.

param.expression: Mean Depth | Variance | Standard Deviation | Difference to Mean | Interquartile Range | Kurtosis
param.name: Statistics_Computed
param.dialogReference:
Up to three different depth statistics can be computed:

  • Mean Depth: The mean of all cell values in the focal neighborhood.

  • Variance: The second central moment of the distribution of all cell values in the focal neighborhood.

  • Standard Deviation: The extent of deviation of all cell values in the focal neighborhood from the mean value. Also defined as the square root of variance.

  • Difference to Mean: The relative difference between the current cell and the mean. This is computed as the difference between the current cell and the mean depth divided by the range in the neighbhorhood.

  • Interquartile Range: Interquartile range (IQR), a measure of variability, is the difference between the 75th percentile and 25th percentile of all values in the focal neighborhood.

  • Kurtosis: A descriptor of the shape of the distribution of all values in the focal neighborhood. More precisely, Kurtosis is defined as the fourth central moment divided by the square of the variance. This tool uses Fisher's definition of Kurtosis, where 3 is subtracted from the result to give a value of 0.0 for a perfectly normal distribution. The calculations are not corrected for statistical bias.

Note: At this time, interquartile range and kurtosis can only be calculated for input rasters less than 2.0 GB in size and with neighborhood sizes less than 75. These statistics will also not be calculated for cells that reside on the border of the input raster where the focal neighborhood includes cells with no data.
param.pythonReference:
Up to three different depth statistics can be computed:

  • Mean Depth: The mean of all cell values in the focal neighborhood.

  • Variance: The second central moment of the distribution of all cell values in the focal neighborhood.

  • Standard Deviation: The extent of deviation of all cell values in the focal neighborhood from the mean value. Also defined as the square root of variance.

  • Difference to Mean: The relative difference between the current cell and the mean. This is computed as the difference between the current cell and the mean depth divided by the range in the neighbhorhood.

  • Interquartile Range: Interquartile range (IQR), a measure of variability, is the difference between the 75th percentile and 25th percentile of all values in the focal neighborhood.

  • Kurtosis: A descriptor of the shape of the distribution of all values in the focal neighborhood. More precisely, Kurtosis is defined as the fourth central moment divided by the square of the variance. This tool uses Fisher's definition of Kurtosis, where 3 is subtracted from the result to give a value of 0.0 for a perfectly normal distribution. The calculations are not corrected for statistical bias.

Note: At this time, interquartile range and kurtosis can only be calculated for input rasters less than 2.0 GB in size and with neighborhood sizes less than 75. These statistics will also not be calculated for cells that reside on the border of the input raster where the focal neighborhood includes cells with no data.

tool.summary: Provides a set of useful depth summary statistics, including mean depth, variance, standard deviation, interquartile range, and kurtosis. These metrics can be helpful predictors in understanding benthic zones, particularly when used for habitat classification.
tool.usage:
• Saves a raster of each chosen statistic to the specified output workspace.

  • Computes each statistic using a specified neighborhood size, which is the size of the square window of cells used to calculate the value of each cell in the result raster. For more information, see How Focal Statistics Work

Note: At this time, interquartile range and kurtosis can only be calculated for input rasters less than 2.0 GB in size and with neighborhood sizes less than 75. These statistics will also not be calculated for cells that reside on the border of the input raster where the focal neighborhood includes cells with no data.
